 'https://github.com/davidahmed/wiper': ('\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         'Wiper is a browser plugin (currently '
                                         'Firefox) that strips search engine '
                                         '(currently Google) results based on '
                                         'your custom blacklist.\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         'Allows for adding and removing '
                                         "user's own blacklist using "
                                         'view>sidebar>Wiper.\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         'Available on Firefox Add-ons\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         'here\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         'Targets\n'
                                         '\n'
                                         '            google.*/search\n'
                                         '           \n'
                                         'and removes results that are in the '
                                         'blacklist (defined in the scripts).',
                                         'Estimate reading time: 0 minutes'),
 'https://nullprogram.com/blog/2020/05/24/': ('\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Latency in Asynchronous Python\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'May 24, 2020\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'nullprogram.com/blog/2020/05/24/\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'This week I was debugging a '
                                              'misbehaving Python program that '
                                              'makes\n'
                                              'significant use of\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Python’s asyncio\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '. The program would\n'
                                              'eventually take very long '
                                              'periods of time to respond to '
                                              'network\n'
                                              'requests. My first suspicion '
                                              'was a CPU-heavy coroutine '
                                              'hogging the\n'
                                              'thread, preventing the socket '
                                              'coroutines from running, but '
                                              'an\n'
                                              'inspection with\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      pdb\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'showed this wasn’t the case. '
                                              'Instead, the\n'
                                              'program’s author had made a '
                                              'couple of fundamental mistakes '
                                              'using\n'
                                              'asyncio. Let’s discuss them '
                                              'using small examples.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Setting the stage: There’s a '
                                              'heartbeat coroutine that '
                                              '“beats” once per\n'
                                              'second. A real program would '
                                              'send out a packet as the '
                                              'heartbeat, but\n'
                                              'here it just prints how late it '
                                              'was scheduled.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'async def heartbeat():\n'
                                              '    while True:\n'
                                              '        start = time.time()\n'
                                              '        await asyncio.sleep(1)\n'
                                              '        delay = time.time() - '
                                              'start - 1\n'
                                              "        print(f'heartbeat delay "
                                              "= {delay:.3f}s')\n"
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Running this with\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      asyncio.run(heartbeat())\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              ':\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'It’s consistently 1ms late, but '
                                              'good enough, especially '
                                              'considering\n'
                                              'what’s to come. A program that\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'only\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'sends a heartbeat is pretty\n'
                                              'useless, so a real program will '
                                              'be busy working on other '
                                              'things\n'
                                              'concurrently. In this example, '
                                              'we have little 10ms payloads of '
                                              'work to\n'
                                              'do, which are represented by '
                                              'this\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      process()\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'function:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'JOB_DURATION = 0.01  # 10ms\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'async def process():\n'
                                              '    time.sleep(JOB_DURATION) # '
                                              'simulate CPU time\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'That’s a synchronous sleep '
                                              'because it’s standing in for '
                                              'actual CPU work.\n'
                                              'Maybe it’s parsing JSON in a '
                                              'loop or crunching numbers in '
                                              'NumPy. Use\n'
                                              'your imagination. During this '
                                              '10ms no other coroutines can be '
                                              'scheduled\n'
                                              'because this is, after all, '
                                              'still\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'just a single-threaded program\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'JOB_COUNT = 200\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'async def main():\n'
                                              '    '
                                              'asyncio.create_task(heartbeat())\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    await asyncio.sleep(2.5)\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              "    print('begin processing')\n"
                                              '    count = JOB_COUNT\n'
                                              '    for _ in range(JOB_COUNT):\n'
                                              '        '
                                              'asyncio.create_task(process())\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    await asyncio.sleep(5)\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'This program starts the '
                                              'heartbeat coroutine in a task. '
                                              'A coroutine\n'
                                              'doesn’t make progress unless '
                                              'someone is waiting on it, and '
                                              'that\n'
                                              'something can be a task. So it '
                                              'will continue along '
                                              'independently without\n'
                                              'prodding.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'The arbitrary 2.5 second sleep '
                                              'simulates waiting, say, for a '
                                              'network\n'
                                              'request. In the output we’ll '
                                              'see the heartbeat tick a couple '
                                              'of times,\n'
                                              'then it will create and process '
                                              '200 jobs concurrently. In a '
                                              'real program\n'
                                              'we’d have some way to collect '
                                              'the results, but we can ignore '
                                              'that part\n'
                                              'for now. They’re\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'only\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '10ms, so the effect on the '
                                              'heartbeat should be\n'
                                              'pretty small right?\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'begin processing\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 1.534s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'The heartbeat was delayed for '
                                              '1.5 seconds by a mere 200 tasks '
                                              'each doing\n'
                                              'only 10ms of work each. What '
                                              'happened?\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Python calls the object that '
                                              'schedules tasks a\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'loop\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              ', and this is no\n'
                                              'coincidence. Everything to be '
                                              'scheduled gets put into a loop '
                                              'and is\n'
                                              'scheduled round robin, one '
                                              'after another. The 200 tasks '
                                              'got scheduled\n'
                                              'ahead of the heartbeat, and so '
                                              'it doesn’t get scheduled again '
                                              'until each\n'
                                              'of those tasks either yields (\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      await\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              ') or completes.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'It really didn’t take much to '
                                              'significantly hamper the '
                                              'heartbeat, and,\n'
                                              'with a\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'dumb bytecode compiler\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              ', 10ms may not be much work at '
                                              'all.\n'
                                              'The lesson here is to avoid '
                                              'spawning many tasks if latency '
                                              'is an\n'
                                              'important consideration.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'A semaphore is not the answer\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'My first idea at a solution: '
                                              'What if we used a semaphore to '
                                              'limit the\n'
                                              'number of “active” tasks at a '
                                              'time? Then perhaps the '
                                              'heartbeat wouldn’t\n'
                                              'have to compete with so many '
                                              'other tasks for time.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'WORKER_COUNT = 4  # max '
                                              '"active" jobs at a time\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'async def '
                                              'main_with_semaphore():\n'
                                              '    '
                                              'asyncio.create_task(heartbeat())\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    await asyncio.sleep(2.5)\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    sem = '
                                              'asyncio.Semaphore(WORKER_COUNT)\n'
                                              '    async def process():\n'
                                              '        await sem.acquire()\n'
                                              '        '
                                              'time.sleep(JOB_DURATION)\n'
                                              '        sem.release()\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              "    print('begin processing')\n"
                                              '    for _ in range(JOB_COUNT):\n'
                                              '        '
                                              'asyncio.create_task(process())\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    await asyncio.sleep(5)\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'When the heartbeat sleep '
                                              'completes, about half the jobs '
                                              'will be complete\n'
                                              'and the other half blocked on '
                                              'the semaphore. So perhaps the '
                                              'heartbeat\n'
                                              'gets to skip ahead of all the '
                                              'blocked tasks since they’re not '
                                              'yet ready\n'
                                              'to run?\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'begin processing\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 1.537s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'It made no difference '
                                              'whatsoever because the tasks '
                                              'each “held their\n'
                                              'place” in line in the loop! '
                                              'Even reducing\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      WORKER_COUNT\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'to 1 would have\n'
                                              'no effect. As soon as a task '
                                              'completes, it frees the task '
                                              'waiting next\n'
                                              'in line. The semaphore does '
                                              'practically nothing here.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Solving it with a job queue\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Here’s what does work: a\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'job queue\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '. Create a queue to be '
                                              'populated\n'
                                              'with coroutines (not tasks), '
                                              'and have a small number of '
                                              'tasks run jobs\n'
                                              'from the queue. Since this is a '
                                              'real solution, I’ve made this '
                                              'example\n'
                                              'more complete.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'async def main_with_queue():\n'
                                              '    '
                                              'asyncio.create_task(heartbeat())\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    await asyncio.sleep(2.5)\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    queue = '
                                              'asyncio.Queue(maxsize=1)\n'
                                              '    async def worker():\n'
                                              '        while True:\n'
                                              '            coro = await '
                                              'queue.get()\n'
                                              '            await coro\n'
                                              '            queue.task_done()\n'
                                              '    workers = '
                                              '[asyncio.create_task(worker())\n'
                                              '                   for _ in '
                                              'range(WORKER_COUNT)]\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              "    print('begin processing')\n"
                                              '    for _ in range(JOB_COUNT):\n'
                                              '        await '
                                              'queue.put(process())\n'
                                              '    await queue.join()\n'
                                              "    print('end processing')\n"
                                              '\n'
                                              '    for w in workers:\n'
                                              '        w.cancel()\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    await asyncio.sleep(2)\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'The\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      task_done()\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'and\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      join()\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'methods make it trivial '
                                              'synchronize on\n'
                                              'full job completion. I also '
                                              'take the time to destroy the '
                                              'worker tasks.\n'
                                              'It’s harmless to leave them '
                                              'blocked on the queue. They’ll '
                                              'be garbage\n'
                                              'collected so it’s not a '
                                              'resource leak. However, CPython '
                                              'complains about\n'
                                              'garbage collecting running '
                                              'tasks because it looks like a '
                                              'mistake — and\n'
                                              'it usually is.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'If you read carefully you might '
                                              'have noticed the queue’s '
                                              'maximum size is\n'
                                              'set to 1: not much of a '
                                              '“queue”!\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Go\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'developers will recognize this\n'
                                              'as an\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'unbuffered channel\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              ', the default and most common '
                                              'kind of channel.\n'
                                              'So it’s more a synchronized '
                                              'meeting point between producer '
                                              '(\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      put()\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              ') and\n'
                                              'consumer (\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      get()\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              '). The producer waits at the '
                                              'queue with a job until a\n'
                                              'task is free to come take it. A '
                                              'task waits at the queue until a '
                                              'producer\n'
                                              'arrives with a job for it.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'begin processing\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.014s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.020s\n'
                                              'end processing\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.002s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'The output shows that the '
                                              'impact to the heartbeat was '
                                              'modest — about\n'
                                              'the best we could hope for from '
                                              'async/await — and the '
                                              'heartbeat\n'
                                              'continued while jobs were '
                                              'running. The more concurrency — '
                                              'the more\n'
                                              'worker tasks running on the '
                                              'queue — the greater the '
                                              'latency.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Note: Increasing the\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      WORKER_COUNT\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'in this toy example won’t have '
                                              'an\n'
                                              'impact on latency since the '
                                              'jobs aren’t actually '
                                              'concurrent. They start,\n'
                                              'run, and complete before '
                                              'another worker task can draw '
                                              'from the queue.\n'
                                              'Putting a couple awaits in\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      process()\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'allows for concurrency:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'WORKER_COUNT = 200\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'async def process():\n'
                                              '    await asyncio.sleep(0.01)\n'
                                              '    time.sleep(JOB_DURATION)\n'
                                              '    await asyncio.sleep(0.01)\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Since there are so many worker '
                                              'tasks, this is back to the '
                                              'initial\n'
                                              'problem:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'begin processing\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 1.655s\n'
                                              'end processing\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              'heartbeat delay = 0.001s\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'As\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      WORKER_COUNT\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'decreases, so does heartbeat '
                                              'latency.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Unbounded queues\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Here’s another defect from the '
                                              'same program. Create an '
                                              'unbounded queue,\n'
                                              'a producer, and a consumer. The '
                                              'consumer prints the queue size '
                                              'so we can\n'
                                              'see what’s happening:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'async def producer_consumer():\n'
                                              '    queue = asyncio.Queue()\n'
                                              '    done = asyncio.Condition()\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    async def producer():\n'
                                              '        for i in '
                                              'range(100_000):\n'
                                              '            await queue.put(i)\n'
                                              '        await queue.join()\n'
                                              '        async with done:\n'
                                              '            done.notify()\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    async def consumer():\n'
                                              '        while True:\n'
                                              '            await queue.get()\n'
                                              "            print(f'qsize = "
                                              "{queue.qsize()}')\n"
                                              '            queue.task_done()\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    '
                                              'asyncio.create_task(producer())\n'
                                              '    '
                                              'asyncio.create_task(consumer())\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    async with done:\n'
                                              '        await done.wait()\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'The output of this program '
                                              'begins:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'qsize = 99999\n'
                                              'qsize = 99998\n'
                                              'qsize = 99997\n'
                                              'qsize = 99996\n'
                                              '...\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'So the entire queue is '
                                              'populated before the consumer '
                                              'does anything at\n'
                                              'all: tons of latency for '
                                              'whatever is being consumed. '
                                              'Since the queue is\n'
                                              'unbounded, the producer never '
                                              'needs to yield. You might be '
                                              'tempted to\n'
                                              'use\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      asyncio.sleep(0)\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'in the producer to yield '
                                              'explicitly:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    async def producer():\n'
                                              '        for i in '
                                              'range(100_000):\n'
                                              '            await queue.put(i)\n'
                                              '            await '
                                              'asyncio.sleep(0)  # yield\n'
                                              '        await queue.join()\n'
                                              '        async with done:\n'
                                              '            done.notify()\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'This even seems to work! The '
                                              'output looks like this:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'qsize = 0\n'
                                              'qsize = 0\n'
                                              'qsize = 0\n'
                                              'qsize = 0\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'However, this is fragile and '
                                              'not a real solution. If the '
                                              'consumer yields\n'
                                              'just two times in its own loop, '
                                              'its nearly back to where we '
                                              'started:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '    async def consumer():\n'
                                              '        while True:\n'
                                              '            await queue.get()\n'
                                              "            print(f'qsize = "
                                              "{queue.qsize()}')\n"
                                              '            queue.task_done()\n'
                                              '            await '
                                              'asyncio.sleep(0)\n'
                                              '            await '
                                              'asyncio.sleep(0)\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'The output shows that the '
                                              'producer gradually creeps ahead '
                                              'of the\n'
                                              'consumer. On each consumer '
                                              'iteration, the producer '
                                              'iterates twice:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'qsize = 0\n'
                                              'qsize = 1\n'
                                              'qsize = 2\n'
                                              'qsize = 3\n'
                                              '...\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'There’s a really simple '
                                              'solution to this:\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Never, ever use unbounded\n'
                                              'queues.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'In fact\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'every unbounded\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '       asyncio.Queue()\n'
                                              '      \n'
                                              'is a bug\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '.\n'
                                              'It’s a serious API defect that '
                                              'asyncio allows unbounded queues '
                                              'to be\n'
                                              'created at all. The default\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      maxsize\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'should have been 1, not '
                                              'infinite,\n'
                                              'and\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '      maxsize=0\n'
                                              '     \n'
                                              'should raise an error.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Important takeaways\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'The default\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '       asyncio.Queue()\n'
                                              '      \n'
                                              'is\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'always\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'wrong.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '       asyncio.sleep(0)\n'
                                              '      \n'
                                              'is\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'nearly always\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'wrong.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Use a\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '       maxsize=1\n'
                                              '      \n'
                                              'job queue instead of spawning '
                                              'many identical tasks.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Python linters should be '
                                              'updated to warn about 1 and 2 '
                                              'by default.\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'python\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              'Have a comment on this article? '
                                              'Start a discussion in my\n'
                                              '\n'

                                              '\n'
                                              'by sending an email to\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '~skeeto/public-inbox@lists.sr.ht\n'
                                              '\n'
                                              '\n'

                                                                                          'a '

                                                                                          'Company '
                                                                                          'or '

                                                                                          '\n'
                                                                                          '\n'
                                                                                          '\n'
                                                                                          "AWN's "
                                                                                          '(AS131445) '
                                                                                          'network '
                                                                                          'connects '
                                                                                          'directly '
                                                                                          'with '
                                                                                          'AIS '
                                                                                          '(AS45430), '
                                                                                          'in '
                                                                                          'fact '
                                                                                          'AIS '
                                                                                          'is '
                                                                                          'their '

 'https://vimota.me/writing/beyond-remote': ('\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'On Monday, Twitter and Square '
                                             'announced they were going '
                                             'remote-first as a company. Three '
                                             'days later Facebook and Shopify '
                                             'had similar announcements. Since '
                                             'then, Twitter and every one of '
                                             'my group chats have been lit up '
                                             'with discussions on what the '
                                             'implications of these changes '
                                             'will be on the future of work. '
                                             "I've been interested in this "
                                             'topic for a while now, even '
                                             'before going remote myself, so I '
                                             "thought I'd share my views on "
                                             'what we could expect to see in '
                                             'the next decade. Although this '
                                             "is largely speculation, it's "
                                             'informed by my last two years of '
                                             'working remotely at Kaggle (a '
                                             'company acquired by Google), and '
                                             'being a member of a partly '
                                             'distributed team before that. '
                                             "I've also written about\n"
                                             '\n'
                                             'effectively working as a '
                                             'remote-first team\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'with my teammate Meg.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Overcorrecting\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'The first thing I thought when '
                                             'hearing these announcements was '
                                             'how drastic they sounded. '
                                             'Despite what being forced to WFH '
                                             'overnight due to covid seems to '
                                             'imply,\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'remote is not a switch you can '
                                             'flip on for a company\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '. A lot of teams that may be '
                                             'working effectively today may '
                                             'just be carrying the momentum '
                                             'they had built while being '
                                             'together in an office. Employees '
                                             'are under an enormous amount of '
                                             'stress during this switch, '
                                             'especially with spouses and kids '
                                             'at home, which may prove to not '
                                             'be sustainable long term. As '
                                             'much as I believe the future to '
                                             'be largely remote-driven, I have '
                                             'a hard time imagining tens or '
                                             'hundreds of thousands of '
                                             'employees becoming remote '
                                             'overnight being able to sustain '
                                             'that productively.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Working remotely is still in the '
                                             "early days. Though it's been "
                                             'proven to work at certain '
                                             "companies, they've tended to be "
                                             'small teams doing a small range '
                                             'of work (ie. web development). '
                                             'It may be the case that we find '
                                             'out that it actually works for '
                                             'most types of knowledge work and '
                                             "company sizes - but that's not "
                                             "yet the case. Don't get me "
                                             "wrong, I'm very excited about "
                                             'the prospect of so many remote '
                                             'opportunities coming online, and '
                                             'having a larger sample size to '
                                             'make conclusions on its '
                                             'effectiveness, but to make such '
                                             'drastic company shifts without '
                                             'more experience seems risky to '
                                             'me.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'The two open questions I have '
                                             'about remote work remain 1) Can '
                                             'large companies continue to '
                                             'propagate their culture when '
                                             'employees are no longer in an '
                                             'office (for a cynical take on '
                                             'this, see Matt Levine covering\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'this transition in banking '
                                             'culture\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             ') and 2) Is there a set of work '
                                             'that is untenable in a remote '
                                             'environment and if so how much '
                                             "of a tech company's work falls "
                                             'under that?\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'I suspect that the answer to the '
                                             'first question is yes, but only '
                                             'if they do so deliberately. Most '
                                             'companies will try to just '
                                             'enforce the same type of '
                                             'activities and processes they '
                                             'had before but digitally, what I '
                                             'call lift-and-shifting culture. '
                                             'Those might work short term, but '
                                             'will gradually produce unhappy '
                                             'and less productive employees. '
                                             'The companies that do best in '
                                             'this environment are the ones '
                                             'that consciously focus on '
                                             'recreating their set of values, '
                                             'expectations, and processes into '
                                             'remote-first ones. Everyone is '
                                             'still learning how to do this, '
                                             'and\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'this\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'was our best stab at documenting '
                                             "Kaggle's approach.\n"
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'The second question, though, is '
                                             "anyone's guess. I don't think "
                                             "there's been enough evidence to "
                                             'determine whether distributed '
                                             'teams can be just as effective '
                                             'in all range of tasks. Most '
                                             'examples we have today of remote '
                                             'teams are small self-selected '
                                             'groups of people that likely '
                                             'bias towards more independent '
                                             "and effective workers. I'm "
                                             'looking forward to seeing the '
                                             'effects on the output of '
                                             'companies transitioning.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Heterogeneous Implementations\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Much of the discussion going on '
                                             'has been dominated by absolutes: '
                                             'the future is remote, or this '
                                             'experiment will fail and '
                                             'everyone will go back to '
                                             'offices. The premise seems wrong '
                                             'to me, remote is more of a '
                                             'spectrum than a binary choice. '
                                             'My bet is on the future being '
                                             'much more heterogeneously remote '
                                             'than people guess. I suspect '
                                             'there will be dozens of remote '
                                             'configurations:\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'extreme "nomad" companies\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '(employees can work any place at '
                                             'any time),\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'co-timezone-located\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '(you can live anywhere within '
                                             'this timezone),\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'office-centric remote-flexible\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '(we expect you to be based in '
                                             'the office but can be remote for '
                                             'periods of time, ie. WFH '
                                             'fridays, month in Hawaii).\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             "It's this diversification of "
                                             'work styles that will most '
                                             "benefit employees. You'll be "
                                             'able to pick - or at least apply '
                                             'to - whatever company subscribes '
                                             'to your ideal lifestyle. And '
                                             'that might even change during '
                                             'your life: perhaps in your '
                                             'twenties you prefer to be '
                                             "nomadic, but in your 40s you'd "
                                             'like to have the stable work '
                                             'hours of having teammates in '
                                             'your timezone.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Offices\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'The Office is not dead, but it '
                                             'will change. Even in my two '
                                             'years of being "remote", I still '
                                             'went into the office at least '
                                             "three times a week. I'd consider "
                                             'myself right in the median on '
                                             'the social spectrum, and tend to '
                                             'get a bit cabin feverish if I '
                                             "don't see people for a couple of "
                                             'days - having some sort of '
                                             'office is a requirement for me '
                                             'long term. It may not be the '
                                             'case for everyone, but the '
                                             'majority of people will still '
                                             'want a space where they can work '
                                             'with and around others outside '
                                             'of their home. WeWork is an '
                                             'obvious example of this trend, '
                                             'but you also see this with '
                                             'digital nomads living in group '
                                             'houses and planning trips '
                                             'together.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Corporate offices will have to '
                                             'adjust to this new reality, as '
                                             'employees come and go whenever '
                                             'it suits them. Offices will '
                                             'become more so spaces to '
                                             'collaborate and socialize, '
                                             'between the focused remote '
                                             'sessions. Events and internal '
                                             'conferences will bring '
                                             'distributed teammates into one '
                                             "space to reset the company's "
                                             '"half-life of trust".\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'I was lucky that Google had 3 '
                                             'offices in Seattle, which I '
                                             'could pick from. I had an '
                                             'official desk in one building, '
                                             'but would really just go into '
                                             'whatever office I felt like each '
                                             'day depending on which '
                                             'colleagues I wanted to meet up '
                                             'with or cafes I wanted to visit. '
                                             'The ability to change '
                                             'environments really helps me '
                                             'feel recharged while working. '
                                             'Having the ability to hop '
                                             'between offices, will give '
                                             'employees the freedom to pick '
                                             'the work environment where they '
                                             "work the best - whether that's a "
                                             'WeWork cubicle, loud coffee shop '
                                             'or their cabin in the woods.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Wages\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'The most contentious topic '
                                             'brought up in these discussions '
                                             'has been the impact going remote '
                                             'will have on wages. Personally, '
                                             "I can't see a way that this "
                                             'would increase wages: a larger '
                                             'supply of workers can only bring '
                                             'down pay. The only possibility '
                                             'for salaries to remain unchanged '
                                             'would be if all the best talent '
                                             'is already maximally hired for, '
                                             'despite location restrictions, '
                                             'but that seems very unlikely.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'The other side of the equation '
                                             'is that employees no longer need '
                                             'to live in one of five cities to '
                                             'participate in 90% of the best '
                                             'paying jobs. Moving to cheaper '
                                             'cities, while being paid less, '
                                             'may or may not benefit you - it '
                                             'depends on the math for your '
                                             'particular case. That being '
                                             'said, I think the people who '
                                             'stand to gain the most are those '
                                             'with families or expensive cost '
                                             'of living, where the local rates '
                                             'dominate their spending.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Most young engineers who moved '
                                             'SF or NY, to live frugally in '
                                             'small apartments while saving '
                                             'most of their salary, had a '
                                             'comparative advantage to others '
                                             'with families or other ties that '
                                             'prevented them from moving to '
                                             'the highest paid cities. In the '
                                             'long term, that advantage will '
                                             'mostly go away, since at the '
                                             'margin people will move out of '
                                             'the expensive cities, bringing '
                                             'down competition for talent in '
                                             'hotspots. I suspect the\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'multipliers companies use to '
                                             'determine wage per city\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'will even out to the efficient '
                                             'frontier of wage to cost of '
                                             'living as employees allocate '
                                             'themselves to the optimal '
                                             'locations.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'The one exception I can think of '
                                             "where this shift won't lower "
                                             'rates is where a person has a '
                                             'monopoly on talent or brand. As '
                                             'remote makes undifferentiated '
                                             'roles more competitive (ie. a '
                                             '"unit\' of software engineer, '
                                             'sales person, or marketing '
                                             'manager), certain talent will '
                                             'find a way to stand out and be '
                                             'unique in their market. That '
                                             'might mean building up a '
                                             'personal brand that brings value '
                                             'to a company beyond the raw '
                                             'output of your work, things like '
                                             'Twitter recognition, '
                                             'conferences, writing, or open '
                                             'source contributions. It could '
                                             'also mean developing a strong '
                                             'network that will help you get '
                                             'hired before you even have to '
                                             'compete with others. This has '
                                             'been my biggest take away from '
                                             'thinking about the future of '
                                             'remote work: those with the '
                                             'highest wages will be the ones '
                                             'who invest in differentiating '
                                             'themselves since they will be of '
                                             'limited supply (only one "you") '
                                             'with infinite demand (every '
                                             'company in the world, not just '
                                             'those in your 100 mile radius).\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Despite being extremely '
                                             'optimistic about the future of '
                                             'remote work, I find the current '
                                             'narrative around it fairly '
                                             'narrow, overrated and '
                                             "repetitive. There's a lot of "
                                             'focus on where people will live '
                                             'and how wages will change, but '
                                             'not enough on what work will '
                                             'actually look like and how '
                                             'culture needs to adapt to it. '
                                             'The transition to remote by so '
                                             'many companies, this quickly, is '
                                             'going to provide a lot of '
                                             'material for a future generation '
                                             'of company builders to study. '
                                             'However this goes, we have an '
                                             'exciting decade ahead of us.\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'Discuss or share this post\n'
                                             '\n'
                                             'here\n'

                                                                                                        'the '
